Whats up guys...
 
 Just today I was accepted into ITT Technical school. I Enrolled myself into the Information Technology - Computer Networking class for my Assosiates Degree. I am 25 and I have been working with computers for years...not just on them..but bulding them and diagnosing them. It was a HUGE step in my life. Here is my question to you all... I have Nobody else to ask this stuff..
 
 What advice do you all have for my jump into this industry? How should I approach this class... There are tricks of every trade...and I know there are some network admistrators on here as well as students... Believe me, I am a friend to all here, but I need some friendly advice on this. Your responces are recieved with all respect.
 
 Thanks,
 
 Bishop

1) Go to class
 2) Don't get frustrated
 3) Don't give up
 
 thats all you need to know

I have never been a network administrator. I have hired (and fired) many of them. 
 
 First, congratulations on choosing a sensible school for what you are after. You will find a job quicker than somebody who foolishly invested 4 years in getting an education that is 10 years out of date in IT. 
 
 Second, learn to program in C. Not C#, visual C or any of that other nonsense. C. There are 18 ads int he kansas city newspaper looking for networking guys who can program in C. EVERYBODY can program in VB. Most folks can program in Java and C#. Network admin guys who can program in C are a little harder to come by, and in great demand, since most large companies have older programs that are wrtitten in C. I happen to know that yellow freight has been trying to fill a position for a networking guy who can program in C for 2 years now. $84,000.00 per year, and they can't find anybody.
 
 I have just been informed by my own (nosy) networking guy that some trade schools (he cited DeVry) don't necessarily include any programming in their network admin curriculem. If not, get a book, learn C. you will find a job faster if you do. Nosy networking guy agrees. He also recommends paying attention (or learning on your own) Linux, since there is apparently a shortage of guys out there w/ formal training who handle linux well.
 
 Thats about all I can think of, and my nosy networking guy who is leaning on me has 20 minutes to get my laptop fixed or he is going to be looking for a new job, too, so despte the fact that he apparently has several pages of advice, he has to go, too.

I handed him my laptop (at which time the relief of remembering why he was there was clear) and he sat down at my little conference table (actually where my kids color, but "coloring table" sounds unprofessional) and started chechinkg things that I ahd already checked.

Then he came over and put his head 3 inches from my ear, took over my mouse so he could scroll through all the tabs I had open, read all my forum replies, and then an Email from my wife, all the while jabbering about how hard it is to be a network admin.
